close_symbols: Object table/type definitions used by the ObjectId functions (structure(s) that store object names)
Object name maximum length constant(s) (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or equivalent)
int32 (typedef) and relevant return-code constants (e.g. OS_SUCCESS, OS_INVALID_POINTER, ...)
List of actual <string.h> functions called by OS_ObjectIdFindByName/OS_ObjectIdGetByName/OS_ObjectIdRelease (e.g. strcmp, strncmp, strlen, strnlen, strcpy, strncpy, memcpy, memcmp) or their wrappers
explanation:
To determine if OS_BinSemGetIdByName can violate the MISRA rule about bounds when using <string.h> functions, the analysis must consider not only the thin wrapper shown but the code that actually touches the sem_name string. Specifically:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro/implementation): This macro may return early on NULL parameters or perform other checks. Its expansion determines whether sem_name can ever be NULL or passed unchecked into downstream code, which affects whether string functions might be invoked on invalid pointers.

- OS_ObjectIdFindByName (implementation): The target simply forwards sem_name to this function. The implementation of OS_ObjectIdFindByName is the primary place where string handling (e.g., name comparisons or copies) will occur; we must inspect it to see which string functions are used and whether they are called with correct bounds.

- OS_ObjectIdGetByName and OS_ObjectIdRelease (implementations): These are the direct callees of OS_ObjectIdFindByName (per the call graph). Any string handling may be done in these helpers, so their code is required to assess buffer usage and bounds checks.

- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE (constant/value): The object type passed to OS_ObjectIdFindByName can change which object table or code path is used. Different object types can have different name-storage policies or lengths; knowing the value lets you identify the correct object table implementation to inspect.

- Object table/type definitions used by the ObjectId functions (structures that store object names): To check for out-of-bounds accesses you must know how object names are stored (fixed-size arrays, allocated buffers, etc.) and where the stored name resides relative to bounds checks performed before any string operations.

- Object name maximum length constant(s) (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or equivalent): Many implementations rely on a compile-time maximum name length. To verify correct use of strncpy/strnlen/strcmp you must know these limits to ensure calls do not read/write past the sem_name or stored-name buffers.

- osal_id_t (typedef): Required to understand how sem_id is used/validated and whether any pointer aliasing or casts in the downstream code could affect string accesses (rare but necessary for full static analysis).

- int32 (typedef) and relevant return-code constants (e.g. OS_SUCCESS, OS_INVALID_POINTER, ...): Needed to follow control flow (early returns on error) and determine whether string-handling code is actually executed under particular conditions.

- List of actual <string.h> functions called by OS_ObjectIdFindByName/OS_ObjectIdGetByName/OS_ObjectIdRelease (e.g. strcmp, strncmp, strlen, strnlen, strcpy, strncpy, memcpy, memcmp) or their wrappers: The MISRA rule targets those standard functions. You must know which of them (and with which argument order/lengths) are invoked in the implementations above to decide if any call can access out-of-bounds memory.

In short: the wrapper (OS_BinSemGetIdByName) itself does not manipulate strings, so the analysis hinges on the implementations and data definitions used by OS_ObjectIdFindByName and its helpers plus any compile-time name-length limits and the precise string.h calls they perform.
